title: Tradesman
text:
A tradesman or tradesperson is a <a href="skilled%20worker">skilled worker</a> that specializes in a particular <a href="Trade%20%28occupation%29">trade</a> (occupation or field of work). Tradesmen usually have <a href="work%20experience">work experience</a>, <a href="on-the-job%20training">on-the-job training</a>, and often formal <a href="vocational%20education">vocational education</a> in contrast to an <a href="apprentice">apprentice</a>, who is learning the trade.
As opposed to a <a href="Master%20craftsman">craftsman</a> or an <a href="artisan">artisan</a> the occupation of a tradesman is not necessarily restricted to manual work.
History.
In <a href="Victorian%20England">Victorian England</a>:
One study of <a href="Caversham%2C%20New%20Zealand">Caversham, New Zealand</a> at the <a href="turn%20of%20the%20century">turn of the century</a> notes that a skilled trade was considered a trade that required an <a href="apprenticeship">apprenticeship</a> to entry. Skilled tradesmen worked either in traditional <a href="handicraft">handicraft</a> workshops or newer factories that emerged during the <a href="Industrial%20Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a>. Traditional handicraft roles included, for example: "<a href="sail-maker">sail-maker</a>, candle-maker, <a href="Cooper%20%28profession%29">cooper</a>, japanner, <a href="lapidary">lapidary</a> and <a href="taxidermist">taxidermist</a>, canister-maker, <a href="furrier">furrier</a>, cap-maker, dobbin-maker, <a href="French%20polish">french-polisher</a>, <a href="baker">baker</a>, miller, <a href="brewer">brewer</a>, <a href="confectioner">confectioner</a>, <a href="watch-maker">watch-maker</a>, <a href="tinsmith">tinsmith</a>, <a href="glazier">glazier</a>, <a href="maltster">maltster</a>, wood-turner, saddler, <a href="shipwright">shipwright</a>, scale-maker, <a href="engraver">engraver</a> and <a href="Cutlery">cutler</a>."
Modern use and list of skilled trades.
Tradesmen are contrasted with unskilled workers, <a href="Agriculture">agricultural</a> workers, and <a href="professional">professional</a>s (those in the learned professions). Skilled tradesmen are distinguished:
There is no definitive list of modern skilled trades, as definitions vary, with some lists being broader than others.
Earnings and social standing.
A British study found that, after taking student loan repayments into account, a higher <a href="apprenticeship">apprenticeship</a> (at level 5 in the <a href="National%20qualifications%20frameworks%20in%20the%20United%20Kingdom">national qualifications frameworks</a>) delivered higher lifetime median earnings than a degree from a university outside the <a href="Russell%20Group">Russell Group</a>. Despite this, polling for the report found that apprenticeships have a lower perceived value than <a href="bachelor%27s%20degree">bachelor's degree</a>s.
Data from the United States shows that, although <a href="vocational%20education">vocational education</a> is usually less financially lucrative in the long term than a bachelor's degree, it can still provide a respectable income at much less cost in time and money for training. Even ten years after graduation, there are many people with a certificate or associate degree who earn more money than those with a B.A.
The average <a href="taxable%20income">taxable income</a> for the top trades in Australia can be up to $100,000, while the average for all Australians is $85,800. As of 2020, the fastest growing trades in demand are Fencing, Handyman and Roofing.
